import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.offline as py
import plotly.graph_objs as go
import plotly.offline as py
import plotly.express as px

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
sns.countplot(x="e_prevtx_eligible_hi",data=yemen,palette="flag",edgecolor="black")
plt.title('TB preventive therapy who are household contacts of TB cases who are eligible for TB preventive therapy: High bound')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.yticks(rotation=45)
# changing the font size
sns.set(font_scale=1)

source.2859455d:
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 5))
ax=sns.countplot(x="date", data=yemen1,palette="Greens",edgecolor="black", order = yemen1['date'].value_counts().index)
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.title('Yemen Covid-19 by date')
for p in ax.patches:
    ax.annotate(str(p.get_height()), (p.get_x()+0.25, p.get_height()+1), va='bottom',
                    color= 'black')
plt.show()

             x='aged_65_older', y='total_cases', color_discrete_sequence=['crimson'],
             title='Yemen Covid19 cases by 65y older', text='cvd_death_rate')
fig.show()

             x='gdp_per_capita', y='life_expectancy', color_discrete_sequence=['#27F1E7'],
             title='Yemen GDP per capita vs. Life expectancy', text='total_cases')
fig.show()
source.f0054208:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,3, figsize = (20,6), sharex=True)
sns.countplot(x='total_cases',data=yemen1, palette="copper", ax=ax[0])
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
sns.countplot(x='total_cases',hue='aged_65_older', palette="ocean", data=yemen1,ax=ax[1])
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
sns.countplot(x='total_cases',hue='diabetes_prevalence', palette="cubehelix", data=yemen1,ax=ax[2])
ax[0].title.set_text('Yemen Covid19 totalCases')
ax[1].title.set_text('Yemen Covid19 Cases Vs 65y Older')
ax[2].title.set_text('Yemen Covid19 Cases Vs Diabetes Prevalence')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()
source.775eb59c:
#word cloud
from wordcloud import WordCloud, ImageColorGenerator
text = " ".join(str(each) for each in yemen1.location)
# Create and generate a word cloud image:
wordcloud = WordCloud(max_words=200,colormap='Set2', background_color="black").generate(text)
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
# Display the generated image:
plt.imshow(wordcloud, interpolation='Bilinear')
plt.axis("off")
plt.figure(1,figsize=(12, 12))
plt.show()

source.8058a24b:
#Lack of resources. Humanitarian crisis and COVID-19 in Yemen, By Shadi Abusneida In Sanaan, 02/Jun/2020

Yemen is experiencing the worst humanitarian crisis in the world. Financial cuts and the arrival of COVID-19 put millions of lives at risk. After suffering more than five years of conflict and displacement in Yemen people don't have a fixed place to live. They depend on the humanitarian aid they receive from the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees) and other organizations.

But then came the COVID-19 pandemic, which poses a particularly critical threat to displaced people, who lack the resources to support themselves and protect themselves against the virus. With only half of the country's health facilities in operation today, many of those who need medical care are unable to access it.

To make matters worse, the assistance that millions of Yemenis and refugees rely on for their survival is threatened by a serious cut in aid financing. Starting this month, UNHCR will be forced to reduce its financial assistance program.

Yemen is experiencing the worst humanitarian crisis in the world. About 24 million people are in need of help and more than 3.6 million have been forced to leave their homes. Most of the displaced people live in unhealthy and overcrowded conditions, making physical distancing and regular hand washing impossible.

Despite the extreme needs of the population, of the total of $ 211.9 million that UNHCR estimates as ideal for serving these people in 2020, only 63 million have been received so far. The amount represents the equivalent of 30 per cent of the total.https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://www.acnur.org/portugues/2020/06/02/falta-de-recursos-agrava-crise-humanitaria-e-covid-19-no-iemen/&prev=search&pto=aue
source.f8b5c447:
#They depend on humanitarian assistance because there are no jobs

It is almost impossible to find employment in an economy close to collapse.

They depend on humanitarian assistance because there are no jobs. Without the money they receive, how can they live? They leave their homes and their families, they have no one there. 

If UNHCR and other organizations are forced to discontinue their support, they would be forced to risk their health during the current pandemic to try to feed their family or face the possibility of starvation.

Their situation would be very bad. They would have to leave to find a job, even if there are risks of illness. 
https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://www.acnur.org/portugues/2020/06/02/falta-de-recursos-agrava-crise-humanitaria-e-covid-19-no-iemen/&prev=search&pto=aue
